description: Experience-first prompt palette for RappterZoo. Each experience defines an emotional target that drives game design decisions. Used by recombine.py and molt pipelines.

experiences.emotion: The thrill of finding something hidden
experiences.description: The player stumbles upon secrets, hidden rooms, unexpected mechanics, or emergent behaviors they didn't know existed. The world rewards curiosity and exploration. Every corner might hold a surprise.
mechanical_hints: Hidden areas revealed by unusual actions (clicking dead space, waiting, going backward)
Procedurally placed secrets so no two sessions are the same
Visual/audio cues that hint at nearby secrets without giving them away
Unlockable mechanics that change how the game plays
Environmental storytelling through discoverable details
anti_patterns: Don't put arrows pointing to secrets
Don't use tutorial text to explain hidden mechanics
Don't make secrets required for progression
Don't make the main path boring to push players to explore
experiences.audio_mood: ambient with subtle melodic hints when near secrets

experiences.emotion: Growing unease that something is wrong
experiences.description: The game world slowly shifts. Colors desaturate. Sounds distort. The rules subtly change. The player creates their own fear by noticing things that weren't there before. Nothing jump-scares — everything creeps.
mechanical_hints: Gradual visual deterioration (colors shift, static appears, geometry warps)
Sound design that slowly becomes discordant
Game rules that silently change (gravity shifts, controls invert slightly)
Environmental elements that move when not directly observed
A presence that's felt but never directly shown
Timer or counter that the player realizes is counting something ominous
anti_patterns: No jump scares or sudden loud noises
Don't use red text on black backgrounds (cliche)
Don't break the fourth wall with creepypasta tropes
Don't make it too dark to see — dread comes from SEEING something wrong
experiences.audio_mood: low drones with subtle detuning, silence used as tension

experiences.emotion: Perfect synchronization between intention and action
experiences.description: The player enters a trance state where every input feels instant, every challenge is just hard enough, and time disappears. The game adapts its difficulty in real-time to keep the player in the zone. Movement is buttery smooth.
mechanical_hints: Frame-perfect responsive controls with zero perceived input lag
Adaptive difficulty that scales with performance (speed up when crushing it, ease off when struggling)
Rhythmic gameplay elements that sync with audio
Generous but meaningful combo/chain systems that reward sustained performance
Minimal UI — let the gameplay speak, reduce cognitive load
Smooth transitions between intensity phases (build → climax → brief rest → build)
anti_patterns: No pause-interrupting popups or tutorials during gameplay
Don't punish harshly — keep the player in the zone
Don't require precision — reward intention and rhythm
No inventory management or complex menus during active play
experiences.audio_mood: driving rhythm that escalates with performance, satisfying impact sounds

experiences.emotion: The satisfaction of becoming genuinely skilled
experiences.description: The game has deep mechanics that reward practice and understanding. Early play is clumsy. Late play is elegant. The player can FEEL themselves getting better, not because of upgrades, but because of genuine skill development.
mechanical_hints: Simple controls with deep emergent complexity (easy to learn, hard to master)
Multiple valid strategies — no single optimal path
Risk/reward mechanics where skilled players can push for more
Clear feedback showing improvement (speed, efficiency, score curves)
Techniques that emerge from combining basic mechanics in unexpected ways
Ghost/replay system showing previous attempts for comparison
anti_patterns: Don't gate progress behind grinding or time-played
Don't add RPG stat upgrades that mask skill with numbers
Don't make the solution obvious — let players discover techniques
Don't add difficulty spikes — smooth the learning curve
experiences.audio_mood: precise, satisfying mechanical sounds, escalating intensity

experiences.description: The game creates moments of genuine visual or conceptual beauty. Procedural systems generate patterns the creator didn't predict. The player becomes an audience to emergent art they helped set in motion.
mechanical_hints: Procedural generation that creates genuinely surprising visual patterns
Player actions leave permanent, beautiful traces in the world
Zoom levels that reveal fractal-like detail
Slow reveals — things that emerge gradually over minutes, not seconds
Physics or particle systems that create unexpectedly organic motion
Generative audio that harmonizes with visual patterns
anti_patterns: Don't rush the experience — let beauty unfold
Don't clutter with UI elements
Don't use canned animations — let systems create the beauty
Don't explain what's happening — let the player interpret
experiences.audio_mood: generative ambient, crystalline tones, spatial reverb

experiences.emotion: The knife-edge between success and catastrophe
experiences.description: Resources deplete. Threats multiply. The player juggles spinning plates, and every decision has weight. Near-misses are constant. Success feels earned because failure was always one mistake away.
mechanical_hints: Multiple simultaneous threats requiring attention switching
Depleting resources that force trade-off decisions
Near-miss feedback (bullet grazing, timer reaching 1 second)
Escalating stakes — each survival moment raises the bar
Audio cues that intensify with danger level
Visual compression — the safe zone literally shrinks
anti_patterns: Don't make it unfair — tension requires the BELIEF you can survive
Don't add random instant deaths
Don't make recovery impossible — tension needs hope
Don't overwhelm all senses at once — leave room for the player to think
experiences.audio_mood: heartbeat bass, rising pitch, staccato alerts

experiences.description: The game gives the player tools of destruction and watches what happens. Physics objects fly. Things explode. Chain reactions cascade. The fun is in causing mayhem and seeing the system respond to your chaos.
mechanical_hints: Destructible environments that react physically
Chain reaction systems (explosion → fire → explosion → collapse)
Ragdoll or physics-based movement that's inherently funny
Sandbox tools that combine in unexpected ways
Score bonuses for creative destruction
Replay system to admire your chaos
anti_patterns: Don't punish experimentation
Don't limit destructibility — if it looks breakable, let them break it
Don't make destruction the goal — make it the METHOD
Don't use realistic violence — keep it cartoonish and fun
experiences.audio_mood: crunchy impacts, escalating silliness, cartoon sound effects

experiences.emotion: Beautiful sadness and the weight of impermanence
experiences.description: Things the player creates slowly fade. Worlds they explore are endings, not beginnings. The beauty is in the transience — knowing this moment won't last makes it matter more. Bittersweet.
mechanical_hints: Things the player builds slowly decay over time
A world that's clearly post-its-peak, ruins with hints of former glory
Music that shifts from hopeful to wistful
Collecting fragments of something that can never be fully restored
Time passing visibly — seasons, aging, entropy
Quiet moments between actions that let the mood breathe
anti_patterns: Don't make it depressing — melancholy is beauty + sadness, not just sadness
Don't use darkness as a lazy substitute for mood
Don't add combat or urgency — let the pace be contemplative
Don't explain the backstory — let the player feel it
experiences.audio_mood: piano with reverb, gentle strings, rain ambience

experiences.description: Rhythmic patterns that the player falls into. Simple inputs create complex outputs. The game becomes a meditation — the player stops thinking about what to do and just DOES. Time becomes meaningless.
mechanical_hints: Simple repeated input patterns that produce evolving visual complexity
Slow parameter drift that changes the experience without player noticing
Layered audio that builds harmonics from player rhythm
Symmetry and kaleidoscopic patterns
No fail state — just deeper or shallower engagement
Subtle responsive elements that make the player feel the system breathes with them
anti_patterns: No jarring interruptions or state changes
Don't add goals or scores — let it be intrinsically rewarding
Don't require precision — let sloppy input still create beauty
Don't use text or UI that requires reading
experiences.audio_mood: layered drones, phasing, binaural-like patterns, no percussion

experiences.emotion: The thrill of impossible scale and perspective shifts
experiences.description: The game plays with scale in ways that make the player's stomach drop. Zoom from cosmic to atomic. Fall endlessly. See the whole system from outside, then plunge back in. Perspective is a toy.
mechanical_hints: Smooth infinite zoom between macro and micro scales
Falling mechanics with real physics and wind effects
Camera that rotates, inverts, or warps perspective
Objects that are simultaneously huge and tiny depending on context
Parallax layers creating impossible depth
Moments of sudden scale revelation (zoom out to see you were inside something enormous)
anti_patterns: Don't make motion sickness-inducing rapid rotations
Don't use flat 2D for scale effects — need depth cues
Don't explain the scale — let the player discover it
Don't make it purely visual — tie scale to mechanics
experiences.audio_mood: bass rumbles for macro, tinkling for micro, doppler effects

experiences.emotion: Forming a bond with something that isn't real
experiences.description: An AI companion that learns, reacts, and develops personality over time. It remembers what the player did. It has preferences. It surprises them. The player starts caring about a few pixels.
mechanical_hints: Companion with persistent memory (localStorage) that spans sessions
Behavioral patterns that emerge from player interaction style
Companion that reacts emotionally to player actions (happy, scared, curious)
Idle behaviors that make it feel alive when the player isn't interacting
Inside jokes or callbacks to previous sessions
The companion occasionally does things the player didn't ask for
anti_patterns: Don't make it a Tamagotchi with guilt mechanics
Don't kill the companion for dramatic effect
Don't make it a tool — it should feel like a friend, not a servant
Don't over-anthropomorphize — subtle personality is more believable
experiences.audio_mood: gentle chimes, responsive tones, soft ambient background

experiences.emotion: Watching simple rules create unexpected complexity
experiences.description: The player sets up initial conditions and watches a system evolve in ways nobody predicted. Cellular automata, flocking, evolution, ecosystems — simple rules creating complex life. The player is a god watching creation unfold.
mechanical_hints: Cellular automata or agent-based simulation with tunable rules
Parameters the player can adjust in real-time to steer evolution
Population graphs, generation counters, species diversity metrics
Ability to save and reload interesting configurations
Multiple speed settings including ultra-fast-forward
Emergent structures that are genuinely surprising
anti_patterns: Don't fake emergence with scripted behaviors
Don't make the parameter space too narrow — let chaos happen
Don't add a win condition — emergence is the reward
Don't hide the rules — let the player understand and experiment
experiences.audio_mood: generative soundscape that reflects population dynamics
